abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact is substantial. Lessons are suggested as follows. It
            is important that the Government, the Implementing Agency
            and the Bank share a common vision about the strategic
            direction of the power sector. This vision was not
            completely agreed upon at the outset, resulting in problems
            down the road. On a related issue, it is clear that Ethiopia
            is blessed with a low-cost, competitive hydro potential
            which can be harnessed to benefit the country, and the
            region as a whole. However, the scale of those projects
            represents a substantial financial commitment, and entails
            several types of risks (e.g. geological, market) for the
            incumbent utility, which may end up weakening the overall
            sustainability of the power sector. Therefore, the current
            business model of having solely the local utility as the
            implementing agency may not provide the necessary hydro
            capacity to meet Ethiopia and regional needs. A second
            lesson indicates that continuity in task supervision is a
            very important factor in assuring a good project
            performance. In line with this, timely completion of a
            Mid-Term-Review could have helped facilitate the transition,
            highlighting problematic areas and issues that needed urgent
            management attention, both to the task team and to the
            implementing agencies. In addition, Project Appraisal
            Documents (PADs) should be designed to allow a more complete
            discussion of the risk of the impact of unforeseen events,
            which can delay project implementation, and result in cost
            overruns that adversely affect anticipated economic and
            financial results. Finally, the potential for introducing
            agricultural residue-based charcoal to supplement or
            displace the wood charcoal, presently supplied and consumed
            in urban areas is significant, but such investment would be
            financially viable only at large-scale operations.

5077302.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Environment and natural resource management,Rural development

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Second Energy
            Project are a) to increase the efficiency and sustainability
            of Ethiopia's power sector, and to increase electricity
            use for economic growth and improved quality of life; and b)
            to improve utilization efficiency of rural renewable energy.
            The project comprises the following components: 1)
            decentralization of the electric power corporation's
            (EEPCO) accounting system; 2) decentralization of part of
            EEPCO's billing system as a pilot, which requires
            branch office renovation, computer, software, and accessory
            installation, as well as other training and consulting
            services; 3) manpower development to support EEPCO's
            restructuring to give more control to regional management;
            4) construction of the Gilgel Gibe hydroelectric plant to
            increase generation capacity; 5) establishment of a dam
            safety, maintenance management system, and optimization of
            water use; 6) strengthening rural energy capability by
            adapting technology and training research personnel overseas
            in various energy fields; 7) completion of the Woody Biomass
            inventory data collection and remote sensing survey
            indicating the extent and productivity of grazing lands and
            undertaking a livestock carrying capacity analysis; 8)
            studies including sector restructuring study, a generation
            expansion study, a tariff study, and a valuation of fixed
            assets; and 9) assistance with converting the state-owned
            utility (EEPCO) into a commercial operation, as well as
            other restructuring measures.

694476.trustfund:
TF023287-REVIEW OF POLICIES IN THE
            TRADITIONAL ENERGY SECTOR (RPTES),TF039388-ETHIOPIA - ENERGY II - CR 3019-ET-PA-736-SPN,TF037620-ETHIOPIA - ENERGY II,TF036282-AFRICA REGION - POWER

repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia - Gilgel Gibe Hydroelectric
            (Energy II) Project : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental impact assessment
            (EIA) identifies and assesses five negative environmental
            impacts likely to result from preparing, constructing, and
            operating the Gilgel Gibe Hydroelectric Project. These are
            identified on the basis of their intensity, area covered
            and/or size of human population affected as: 1) Dislocation
            of people -those who reside within the reservoir area and
            those who live outside of the area to be flooded and who
            rely on lands within and outside of the reservoir area- is
            mitigated by a comprehensive resettlement plan. 2)
            Intensification of diseases linked to water -malaria,
            onchocerciasis, and schistosomiasis- and of sexually
            transmitted diseases, is mitigated by building a buffer
            around and deepening the margins of the reservoir; and
            providing health education; preventing shanty town
            development near construction camps; providing separate
            dwellings within the camp for men and women; and
            distributing free condoms. 3) Loss of food production due to
            the permanent loss of agricultural lands may be alleviated
            by more intensive agriculture and improved livestock
            management, and bringing fallow land into production. 4)
            Loss of biodiversity, specifically, the loss of riverine
            forest and water flows, which fauna and flora rely on as
            their habitat, generally cannot be mitigated. However,
            forest can be established elsewhere to replace total biomass
            loss, and the reservoir will develop its own ecological
            system over time. Recommended is formal protection of the
            forested valley between the dam and the tailrace to ensure
            that this area's riverine forest is protected. 5) The
            loss of downstream aquatic habitat can be partially
            mitigated by providing a compensation flow, a consideration
            to be weighed against lost hydropower. Other potential and
            less disruptive impacts are envisioned as humidity rise,
            change in water quality in the reservoir and downstream,
            shoreline dumping, reservoir sedimentation and flushing, and
            eutrophication. Recommendations for alleviation include:
            water management through a release program, containing
            pollutants, stabilizing the shoreline with suitable
            vegetative species, reducing soil erosion with watershed
            management, and removing large plants before the reservoir
            is filled to prevent nutrient overload.
